CHEMICALS

mda

MDA



COMMON & BRAND NAMES

Sass or Sassafras [also used for MDMA]

EFFECTS CLASSIFICATION

Euphoric Empathogen; Stimulant; Phenethylamine

CHEMICAL NAME

3,4-methylenedioxyamphetamine

DESCRIPTION


                    Context: 
                    This chunk is from the Erowid website and appears as part of the navigation menu and header for the MDA (3,4-methylenedioxyamphetamine) information page. It includes links to books and resources about psychoactive substances, site support options, and the beginning of the MDA entry covering its common names, classification, and chemical name. This section helps users navigate reference materials and introduces the core data on MDA, a chemical related to MDMA.

content:
Drug: MDA | cid: 1614
Source: erowid | Source description: Information about MDA including basics, effects, dosage, history, legal status, photos, research, media coverage, and links to other resources.
Erowid name: mda
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: MainPage

                    Text: 
                    MDA



COMMON & BRAND NAMES

Sass or Sassafras [also used for MDMA]

EFFECTS CLASSIFICATION

Euphoric Empathogen; Stimulant; Phenethylamine

CHEMICAL NAME

3,4-methylenedioxyamphetamine

DESCRIPTION

MDA is a synthetic empathogen sometimes found in ecstasy tablets. It is closely related to MDMA though its effects are said to be slightly more psychedelic.

BASICS

EFFECTS

IMAGES

HEALTH

LAW

DOSE

CHEMISTRY

GENERAL INFORMATION #

PiHKAL Entry for MDA

RELATED VAULTS #

MDE Vault

MDMA (Ecstasy) Vault

Nutmeg Vault

Herbal MDMA Replacements

HISTORY #

MDA Timeline

ASK EROWID ANSWERS #

Is "Sass" a natural form of MDMA (or MDA)?

ARTICLES & WRITINGS #

Re-examining MDA Duration, by Earth & Fire Erowid

RESEARCH & JOURNAL ARTICLES #

An unusual clandestine laboratory synthesis of [...] - 2012

Effects of MDMA, MDA and MDEA on blood pressure, heart rate [...] - 2006

A bitter pill. Overview of ecstasy (MDMA, MDA) related fatalities - 2004


                    Context: 
                    This chunk is the main summary and resource hub for MDA (3,4-methylenedioxyamphetamine) in the "Chemicals" section of Erowid. It provides core details—chemical name, effects, street names, and description—as well as links to related substances, research articles, user experiences, and other resources about MDA's pharmacology, health effects, law, and history.

                    Context: 
                    This section lists research and journal articles related to MDA (3,4-methylenedioxyamphetamine), including studies comparing its effects with MDMA and MDEA, its subjective effects, use in psychotherapy, and case studies of related fatalities. It is followed by user-submitted MDA experience reports and links to additional resources, all within Erowid’s broader MDA information page.
